title: Mathematics Geometry and Numbers
description: Explore geometry concepts like angles and lines, rational numbers, and comparing quantities for Class 6 students.

subtopics.title: Types of Angles
subtopics.content:
## Types of Angles

Geometry and numbers form an important part of mathematics. A line is a straight path that extends endlessly in both directions. When two lines meet, they form an angle. Angles are measured in degrees. Some common types of angles are:

- **Acute angle**: less than 90°
- **Right angle**: exactly 90°
- **Obtuse angle**: between 90° and 180°
- **Straight angle**: exactly 180°
- **Reflex angle**: greater than 180° but less than 360° [file:1]
subtopics.codeExample:
### Angle Questions:
- What is an acute angle?
- Name an angle that measures exactly 90°.
- How many degrees in a straight angle?

### Practice:
- Classify given angles by type
- Measure angles using a protractor
- Draw examples of each angle type

subtopics.title: Lines and Angle Relationships
subtopics.content:
## Lines and Angle Relationships

When two lines intersect, opposite angles are vertically opposite angles, and they are always equal. Also, when a line cuts two or more parallel lines, it forms corresponding, alternate, and interior angles which have special relationships. [file:1]
subtopics.codeExample:
### Relationship Questions:
- What are vertically opposite angles?
- Define corresponding angles.
- What is true about alternate angles with parallel lines?

### Practice:
- Identify angle pairs in diagrams
- Prove vertically opposite angles are equal
- Solve problems with parallel lines

subtopics.title: Rational Numbers
subtopics.content:
## Rational Numbers

A rational number is a number that can be expressed in the form p/q, where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0. Examples include 2/3, 5/7, and 4. Rational numbers include positive and negative fractions, whole numbers, and integers. [file:1]
subtopics.codeExample:
### Rational Number Questions:
- Define a rational number.
- Give examples of rational numbers.
- Is 4 a rational number? Why?

### Practice:
- Identify rational vs irrational numbers
- Convert mixed fractions to improper
- Perform operations on rational numbers

subtopics.title: Comparing Quantities
subtopics.content:
## Comparing Quantities

Comparing quantities involves finding ratios, percentages, and simple interest. Ratio compares two quantities of the same kind e.g., 2:3. Percentage represents a number as a part of 100 e.g., 40% means 40 out of 100. Simple Interest (SI) is calculated using the formula: $$SI = \frac{P \times R \times T}{100}$$, where P = Principal, R = Rate of interest, T = Time in years. [file:1]
subtopics.codeExample:
### Quantity Questions:
- What is a ratio? Give example.
- Convert 40% to fraction.
- Calculate SI if P=1000, R=5%, T=2 years.

### Practice:
- Find ratios from given data
- Solve percentage problems
- Compute simple interest
